Message.Title: The Ignorance Caucus
Message.Msg: Last week Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, gave what his office told us would be a major policy speech. And we should be grateful for the heads-up about the speech’s majorness. Otherwise, a read of the speech might have suggested that he was offering nothing more than a meager, warmed-over selection of stale ideas. To be sure, Mr. Cantor tried to sound interested in serious policy discussion. But he didn’t succeed — and that was no accident. For these days his party dislikes the whole idea of applying critical thinking and evidence to policy questions. And no, that’s not a caricature: Last year the Texas G.O.P. explicitly condemned efforts to teach “critical thinking skills,” because, it said, such efforts “have the purpose of challenging the student’s fixed beliefs and undermining parental authority.” And such is the influence of what we might call the ignorance caucus that even when giving a speech intended to demonstrate his openness to new ideas, Mr. Cantor felt obliged to give that caucus a shout-out, calling for a complete end to federal funding of social science research. Because it’s surely a waste of money seeking to understand the society we’re trying to change. Want other examples of the ignorance caucus at work? Start with health care, an area in which Mr. Cantor tried not to sound anti-intellectual; he lavished praise on medical research just before attacking federal support for social science. (By the way, how much money are we talking about? Well, the entire National Science Foundation budget for social and economic sciences amounts to a whopping 0.01 percent of the budget deficit.) But Mr. Cantor’s support for medical research is curiously limited. He’s all for developing new treatments, but he and his colleagues have adamantly opposed “comparative effectiveness research,” which seeks to determine how well such treatments work. What they fear, of course, is that the people running Medicare and other government programs might use the results of such research to determine what they’re willing to pay for. Instead, they want to turn Medicare into a voucher system and let individuals make decisions about treatment. But even if you think that’s a good idea (it isn’t), how are individuals supposed to make good medical choices if we ensure that they have no idea what health benefits, if any, to expect from their choices? Still, the desire to perpetuate ignorance on matters medical is nothing compared with the desire to kill climate research, where Mr. Cantor’s colleagues — particularly, as it happens, in his home state of Virginia — have engaged in furious witch hunts against scientists who find evidence they don’t like. True, the state has finally agreed to study the growing risk of coastal flooding; Norfolk is among the American cities most vulnerable to climate change. But Republicans in the State Legislature have specifically prohibited the use of the words “sea-level rise.” And there are many other examples, like the way House Republicans tried to suppress a Congressional Research Service report casting doubt on claims about the magical growth effects of tax cuts for the wealthy. Do actions like this have important effects? Well, consider the agonized discussions of gun policy that followed the Newtown massacre. It would be helpful to these discussions if we had a good grasp of the facts about firearms and violence. But we don’t, because back in the 1990s conservative politicians, acting on behalf of the National Rifle Association, bullied federal agencies into ceasing just about all research into the issue. Willful ignorance matters. O.K., at this point the conventions of punditry call for saying something to demonstrate my evenhandedness, something along the lines of “Democrats do it too.” But while Democrats, being human, often read evidence selectively and choose to believe things that make them comfortable, there really isn’t anything equivalent to Republicans’ active hostility to collecting evidence in the first place. The truth is that America’s partisan divide runs much deeper than even pessimists are usually willing to admit; the parties aren’t just divided on values and policy views, they’re divided over epistemology. One side believes, at least in principle, in letting its policy views be shaped by facts; the other believes in suppressing the facts if they contradict its fixed beliefs. In her parting shot on leaving the State Department, Hillary Clinton said of her Republican critics, “They just will not live in an evidence-based world.” She was referring specifically to the Benghazi controversy, but her point applies much more generally. And for all the talk of reforming and reinventing the G.O.P., the ignorance caucus retains a firm grip on the party’s heart and mind. NYT / 10 Feb '13

Message.Title: NTSB challenges Boeing estimates of 787 battery safety
Message.Msg: NTSB challenges Boeing estimates of 787 battery safety In a blunt briefing Thursday, the chief of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) said the government and Boeing badly underestimated the possibilities for failure of the 787’s lithium-ion batteries. . The sweep of the NTSB investigation, and the agency’s critique of the plane’s testing and certification, suggest the jet-maker has a long way to go before passenger flights can resume. The NTSB chief said the safety assessments Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) made while certifying the 787 lithium-ion batteries for commercial service “were not borne out by what we saw in flight experience.” Boeing estimated, for instance, that a battery problem would cause smoke less than once during 10 million hours of flight, while the plane so far has experienced two incidents in less than 100,000 hours. safety-board member John Goglia said in an interview afterward the briefing that the statistical standard for safety of the 787 batteries had been set too low by the FAA — and “Boeing didn’t even meet the reduced standard.” The NTSB briefing suggested that Boeing will have to redesign and recertify the jet’s battery system for a long-term fix. “The assumptions used to certify the battery must be reconsidered,” said NTSB Chairwoman Deborah Hersman. “The design and certification assessment, and the assumptions that were made, were not borne out by what we saw in flight experience.” The FAA grounded the plane Jan. 16 after a Jan. 7 battery fire at the Boston airport, followed just over a week later by a second event, when a battery smoldering on a flight in Japan forced an emergency landing. Those incidents make clear, said Goglia, that “Boeing didn’t identify and mitigate all the failure modes.” One in 10 million Hersman said Thursday the investigation has pinpointed the start of the Japan Airlines battery fire as a short circuit inside a single cell of the eight-cell battery. The overheating of cell No. 6 spread to all the others and caused the fire, she said. Hersman said Boeing had studied the possibility of such a single-cell short circuit and its effects, in tests during the certification process. Boeing concluded that these tests “showed no evidence of cell-to-cell propagation or fire in the battery,” she said. However, in the fire on the Japan Airlines jet at Boston’s Logan airport, that’s exactly what happened. In another certification test, Hersman said, Boeing studied the possibility that a failure in a single cell would result in smoke emission from the battery and estimated this would happen “less than once in every 10 million flight hours.” “The 787 fleet has accumulated less than 100,000 flight hours,” she said. “Yet there have now been two battery events resulting in smoke less than two weeks apart on two different aircraft.” Goglia said the standard FAA safety requirement to cover the failure of any system critical to flight is that it must not occur more than once in a billion flight hours — which means such a failure is not expected to occur in the life of the fleet. So the 787 battery-safety requirement that assumed a failure once every 10 million flight hours — 100 times more frequently — is already a low bar by FAA standards, he said. Hersman said the NTSB will “examine the safety certification process used by both the FAA and Boeing for the 787 battery design and determine why the hazards identified in this investigation were not mitigated.” Root cause sought The NTSB still hasn’t identified the cause of the initial short circuit Looks like the FAA has some explaining to do. NTSB called them out. Too bad they went with passive monitoring rather than active control (i.e. Tesla's battery cooling system). There will be no weight savings over NiMH if they have to add that, which they should have done in the first place. Hindsight's damned expensive in the airplane manufacturing business When all is said and done, including compensation to carriers with grounded aircraft, this will be a costly lesson for Boeing on their ill-considered rush to outsource, and as with any large corporation, those aresponsible for this debacle need to take the fall. That is why the 2 billion stock buy back is in full protect the stock price for as long as the money holds out, if the stock price drops enough then the CEO’s job is on the line, for those who are asking why the stock price has held as well as it has so far. LAPD Chief Beck was almost apologetic when he announced the "unprecedented" $1 million reward leading to capture/arrest of Dorner and he rationalized: "This is the largest local reward ever offered to our knowledge ... Some may ask, ‘Why so large’” he continued, adding, “This is an act — and make no mistake about it — of domestic terrorism." He went on to opine about the sacrifice of officers, which I totally agree. There is no fair way to put this: double standard, yet we understand and empathize. California had about 1000 police officers involved in search and protection. They need to get this guy and wipe him off the face of the planet ASAP. "Do you think the answer was for the paper delivery to respond with AK 47 fire?" Of course not, but the police did not follow procedure and the incident illustrated what I was trying to say is that the government can lose control of itself and overwhelm the citizens with their greater fire power. Whether that was by mistake or by design. The Second Amendment ot the Constitution was written to protect both the individual and the "free State": "A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed." Notice that it does not say anything about a "foreign" enemy. Is that to be "assumed" or did the founding fathers acknowledge that the threat can be from without and within?

Message.Title: Did our strike in 2000 end up getting us a better offer?
Message.Msg: From: Davaz, Dennis D Sent: Friday, February 08, 2013 6:16 PM To: Rogers, Kyle R Subject: SPEEA: Did our strike in 2000 end up getting us a better offer? Hi Kyle, Good question! For others receiving this note, read Kyle’s question at the bottom, then pop back here for the answer. Most of this is my strike story from 2000, but there’s other good stuff in here, too. I’m Dennis Davaz, a Fabrication Division Core Quality investigator in the SPEEA Technical Bargaining Unit. I work at the Everett site, but report through Fab, and right now I’m supporting our FOD implementation across the Fab MBUs. I’m currently a SPEEA Area Rep in District E14 (bldgs 40-21 & -22), but back during the 40-day strike in 2000 I was the SPEEA Council Rep for the Boeing facility in Spokane (which has since been sold to Triumph). I know SPEEA has recently put out several statements at how many “best and final offers” didn’t end up being best or final back then. The rule of thumb is no matter what the company says, it’s never a best or final offer until we accept it. Boeing executives and Mike Delaney have made a weird statement that they “didn’t leave anything on the table” – I’m sure they meant to say “we put everything we possibly can on the table” in their offer – meaning they aren’t still holding onto any improvements that they can make to this offer if we do reject it and go on strike. Of course that’s not true – it’s a bluff that all companies make. I think the metaphor they were trying for is similar to the football adage to “leave it all on the field” – don’t walk off the field with any reserve of effort you didn’t spend to win the game – but I think they got it wrong. I’m assuming you must be one of the folks who have hired into Boeing since 2000 and weren’t here yourself or weren’t in a SPEEA-represented position back then so may not have followed the play-by-play as closely as those of us who were hip-deep in it. People who did experience the strike in 2000 are supposed to have been telling their stories to the newer folks for just this purpose – to let them know that our contract offer got significantly better and a strike isn’t really as scary as it seems. Back then was the first time I had noticed that the company would cut benefits to the exempt and non-represented employees a year or two ahead of time in order to make the case that they’re just trying to make the benefits the same for all employees. They can get away with imposing cuts onto exempt or non-represented employees and there’s nothing those employees can do about it. But the company has to convince us to accept a contract offer with cuts in it. Back in 2000 the Boeing Negotiation Team tried to get concessions from the IAM, but they weren’t going to budge and started preparing for a strike. The company couldn’t afford one back then either, so Phil Condit intervened and gave the IAM a much better offer with a nice bonus as a carrot. They accepted. SPEEA members had bought into the narrative that we would usually get a fraction of whatever the IAM got – the crumbs left over – and the managers and non-represented employees would get whatever table scraps were left by us. That was just after the McDonald Douglas merger, and we heard that Harry Stonecipher berated Phil about giving in to labor, and he said he would handle the SPEEA negotiation and “show him how to deal with labor”. Our original offer was ugly (though not as bad as the original offer we got this time), but no one thought SPEEA had the balls to really go out on strike. It was rejected by a really high percentage then, too, but lots of people thought we were going to get railroaded into accepting that a bad deal anyway. The second offer we got just shifted the take aways from one thing to another. SPEEA had commissioned independent surveys, and most of our members were responding that they would only support a strike for a week or two before having to cross the picket line and come back to work. SPEEA leaders rightly feared that even a modest strike would end up breaking the union. But then a miracle happened: Harry opened his mouth and showed his contempt for the engineers. He said that “engineers would just have to realize that they weren’t the center of the universe anymore.” It was signaling a big shift in the company from what had been an aerospace engineering-centric, manufacturing-industrial powerhouse toward a MBA-centric, “bean-counters make all the rules” entity. It didn’t matter whether we were building airplanes or selling coffee – business is business, and it’s all about the Benjamins. Back then we had an open shop – you weren’t required to be a member (and thus pay dues) if you were in a SPEEA-represented job. There were lots of free-loaders who didn’t pay dues but got the benefits of the contract and union representation anyway. But when Stonecipher treated the engineering community with such contempt, a majority were so offended that they signed up in droves. The typical membership percentages in the Puget Sound region pre-foot-in-mouth was about 30-some percent – at Spokane it was closer to 50%. Shortly after Harry’s statement, membership in PS doubled to 60-70%, and in Spokane we had 100% of the SPEEA-represented employees signed up as dues-paying members. The negotiations issues had become about basic respect – or the lack of it that the company was demonstrating to the engineers. That’s why you still hear Ray Goforth and others still using that “it’s about Respect” phrase today – to hearken back to what worked in 2000. We were an untested and unproven group back then, and the company had the same data that only some of us would go out on strike, and those that did wouldn’t stay out for long, so they expected they would stomp us good. Our SPEEA Negotiation Team actually recommended to accept the offer! – I think that was a concession coerced by the company that in order to lift the offer from the table and take it to the membership for a vote, the SPEEA Negotiation Team at the time had to endorse the offer – slimy tactic by the company, I know. But by then the membership was just too pissed off. When we did go out it was a major event – people lined the aisle ways and cheered. Many of those that didn’t walk out the first day came out and joined us during that first week, even non-members walked out. Our movement grew stronger rather than weaker over time. Once people were out they discovered it wasn’t as bad as they feared. Then no one wanted to be the first to give in and cross the picket line. If people were hurting or had special needs, each of us pitched in to help out so they didn’t have to cross the line. And we got all kinds of support from the IAM, other unions, and the general public. Even though we were getting better exercise by walking the line, people gained weight because of all the donuts and pizza people dropped off. We had people showing up for picket duty when they weren’t even scheduled because it turned into such a party atmosphere. There were guys who would fire up the barbeque to make pancakes, eggs, & bacon every morning. People would bring guitars or other instruments and sing around the burn barrel. It was awesome. Our mantra became “how long are we going to stay out? – one day longer than necessary to get a good offer.” When we passed the 30-day mark and people had already been missing out on pay days, we still didn’t break. Back then Boeing had delivery contracts with more airlines that had strike escape clauses in them: if Boeing had late deliveries there were steep penalties, unless it was due to a work stoppage lasting over 40 days, then the penalty was dropped. That meant that any strike that resulted in any late deliveries was likely to go at least 40 days so Boeing could at least not pay the penalties. Airlines have gotten wise to this ploy and that provision has been removed from most of the contracts – they knew Boeing was posturing for strikes as excuses to drop penalties on deliveries that would have been late anyway. The airlines don’t care what we do or don’t get in our contract, they just want Boeing to have happy employees getting out good quality airplanes on schedule. Boeing won’t reduce the list price of an airplane if the labor costs are reduced, so they don’t care how much we get out of the profit – they just want a good plane, and they know happy employees are more likely to get them one. That’s why Moral was on the QCDSM metrics scale. [That’s Quality, Cost, Delivery, Safety, and Morale.] What brought the 2000 strike to a head was pressure from the U.S. government because of the trade deficit, from the FAA in particular because Boeing was using unqualified managers to fulfill the Designated Engineering Representative (DER) role – which is equivalent to the AR role now for certifying planes as airworthy – and from the airlines themselves. We weren’t budging, and if anything we were growing more adamant with each day, and each day we were ratcheting up pressure on the company. We finally got a contract offer that was way better than any of us thought we could possibly get and which replaced all the take aways Boeing was trying to strong-arm from us. I believe the acceptance percentage of that offer was somewhere around 78% - higher than a union activist wants an accept percentage to be because that telegraphs to the company that they gave in too much. A company is always looking to provide a contract offer that will be approved by just barely over 50%, meaning they got a contract approved as inexpensively as they could. On the contrary, a union doesn’t want too high an acceptance percentage, because that just means they’ll have to fight that much harder next time to keep the same contract provisions. After we came back from the strike I even had managers from the inside pull me aside and congratulate me for a well-run strike. We got what we wanted, no one got hurt, we came back with no hard feelings so we could all get back to work productively, and we gained universal respect – just what we said we wanted. The IAM was proud of the stand we took, along with many other outside unions. It was only a short time later that we affiliated with the IFPTE, which gave us a connection to the AFL-CIO, which meant we were no longer just an association – we were a real union, on par with the IAM & Teamsters. We also had a majority of us as dues paying members, so we had the ability to institute an Agency Fee, which meant everyone had to pay dues unless they were a Beck Objector – no more free loaders! I think most importantly we gained some self-respect – none of us thought it was possible, and even our union leadership was timid about it, but we surprised everyone, even ourselves. It was the biggest white-collar strike ever, and we had been successful. After we got settled, the company also was shamed into improving the salary increases and benefits for the exempt and non-represented employees – in fairness Boeing had to retract what they had originally imposed on them since both the IAM and SPEEA had avoided the same concessions. There were lots of those employees who thanked us for holding the line on benefit erosion. That was my experience and is my recollection of events – though I’m sure there was an entire range of experiences for various people. Back then Boeing was saying the same thing, that if we didn’t make drastic concessions we would not be competitive and Airbus would walk away with the market. Now it’s 12 years later and Boeing is stronger than ever. Boeing says that they’ll outsource to cheaper sources of labor if we don’t give in – but they’re doing that anyway everywhere they can and in some cases with work that they shouldn’t. In lots of cases they’re ending up paying more in the long run. Boeing is playing on our insecurities in order for us to willingly choose to work for less, no matter how successful our business is. They’re following the GE model of Management by Stress (see attached). Kyle, I remember other sharp but concerned guys saying the same thing back in 1999/2000: “what if we go out on strike and take the financial hit, only to come back and take the same offer?” This isn’t the first dance for our negotiation team. We’re not untested anymore. A strike authorization is a tool they need to get a better offer that they think they can get from the company without a strike! Boeing’s primary goal in this negotiation was to start the process for ridding itself of the pension for both unions (SPEEA & IAM), just like lots of other corporations (GE, IBM, et. al.) are doing successfully. The PR campaign they’re waging is a significant investment to achieve that goal. But their primary responsibility as a company is to make the most money they can. The immediate savings on day one of the current contract offer is nothing – it’s only after years of hiring new employees under the 401(k) that they’ll see a difference at all, and that will only be the delta between what the pension would have cost them and what the 401(k) would end up costing them. It’s not a huge difference. Tangent: they keep talking about how they’ll use that money for R&D – first off, don’t believe it; and second, what kind of company tells it’s employees “we’re buying back stock to make our own stock more valuable, we’re giving larger dividends to shareholders, we’re giving massive increases and bonuses to our executives, profits have never been better, and damn it, business is just so good we want bigger profit margins – but the only way we can pay for R&D and future development programs is by taking money away from future engineers and techs – money that would have gone to a better pension for them will be our investment for future business. If people want a job bad enough in this sluggish job recovery, they’ll take it no matter how bad an offer it is!” If there was any chance that was true, it would be flat out evil. Even the lame excuses they’re giving us aren’t credible. But a work stoppage at a time when our 787 fleet is grounded and costing bazillions each day, not to mention the impact to our other priorities this year (new development programs, rate increases, etc.), would be HUGE. I mean even bigger than Donald Trump “huge”. The Board of Directors won’t allow it. Boeing will bring forward a better offer before a strike takes place. Also, when the IAM goes out on strike it’s a clean break: everything shuts down when they stop work and then it all fires right back up again when they come back to work. When SPEEA goes out on strike it unloads the production system – the IAM bleeds out as much work as they can out of the hopper and loads up a bunch of backlog for us. When we come back in, it take months to recover and get back to healthy equilibrium in the production system. We would lose productivity and effectiveness for a year at our current production levels, let alone having no progress on new programs and rate increases. A common metaphor is that if Boeing production is a car, the IAM is the gas: if there’s no gas you don’t go anywhere; add gas and you’re back on the road – and SPEEA is the oil: if you’re low on oil, you can keep driving, but you’re risking much greater damage. Boeing absolutely can’t afford to let us go out on strike – they would suffer many times over the extent we would. So I think if it really comes down to it and we force the issue, Boeing would have no choice but to keep the pension in place for now because they want to stay in business more than they want to get rid of the pension. Ray Conner and others keep saying “no one wins in a strike”, and they’re right – a strike is the utter break-down of the negotiations process. SPEEA wants to win a better contract offer without having to resort to a strike, but with the company playing hard-ball I can’t guarantee it won’t come down to a work stoppage. If union-represented employees want to avoid concessions when they’re not warranted, occasionally they have to strike and take the personal economic loss to prove to the company that they’re serious and willing to do so – it’s the cost of doing business in order to get the better pay and benefits that union-represented jobs can garner. We don’t ever earn that money back, but we keep our benefits from being eroded, which is worth money on into the future. My answer to “no one wins in a strike” is that you never get back what you give away by accepting a take away contract offer, either. We can win the privilege to keep our pay and benefits honestly market-leading by occasionally investing the cost of lost pay while we’re on strike. The Boeing Company wants you to think you’d be sacrificing your pay for someone else’s (the new hire’s) benefits – that’s how they’re dividing us in order to conquer all. If they’re successful in shifting new hires to 401(k), it’s a guarantee that they’ll end up freezing the pension for the rest of us in the not too distant future. This concession is targeted at the rest of us, too, just not yet – but it’ll be inevitable if we give in now. This might be fun: if you’re familiar with Texas Hold ‘Em, the negotiations process up to this point is like we’ve seen the Flop and we’ve got a good hand, but Boeing is the Big Stack and they’re bluffing - trying to intimidate us into folding before seeing the Turn. The price to see the River card would be us actually walking out on strike. For us to call we’ve got to reject the offer and authorize a strike in order to see the Turn card. Rejecting an offer and authorizing the strike to “see the card” costs us nothing – we’re not actually going out on strike yet, just saying we would in order to see the next offer. Of course there’s another offer available – the money is too good in aerospace for Boeing to fold and quit doing business. If we fold by accepting the offer or not authorizing a strike sanction, Boeing will rake in the pot and chuckle to itself that it successfully bullied us into giving up a winning hand. And they know that once they’ve detected weakness they don’t need to play to get the best cards in future hands – they just keep on psyching out the other player. I wouldn’t be surprised if others would come up with slightly different analogy descriptions on this, but hopefully it helps make the point. I must be Jonesing for a game. Here’s something else we need to consider: if Boeing does reinstate the pension for new hires but takes back some other provision in the current offer that costs us more than what the 401(k) option would have cost new hires, technically they’re giving in on what we said was important to us but giving us the back of their hand at the same time. Advantage Boeing. It’ll be harder for us to keep playing Whack-a-Take-Away from offer to offer and not lose the support we have now. Hopefully Boeing will realize that it only has so many chances before they run out of time, too. We want an offer with no take aways and protection from things getting worse for us through Congressional legislative action – just that simple. We reject the notion that we have to give in on anything and lose out in order to reach a compromise. There’s no reason for us to compromise anything – we’re not overcompensated. I know that’s way more than you asked for, but I hope it helps. I like sharing the strike story in that much detail because it really is a source of pride for all of us. Those of us from Spokane all mostly got along pretty well as coworkers in a small shop before the strike, but our bonds of friendship were well-forged by the burn barrel during those 40 days on the picket line and we’re all still close friends to this day. Hope you don’t mind if I share this question and answer with others, because I’ll wager others are wondering the same thing. Dennis Davaz Dist E14 SPEEA Area Rep 425-931-9316 From: Rogers, Kyle R Sent: Friday, February 08, 2013 5:51 AM To: Nowlin, Dan C Subject: RE: New videos explain contract offers and recommendations (and a personal appeal) Dan, The one thing she does not state in this appeal is whether or not in 2000 the “Best and Final Offers” got any better. The risk I see is going on a 40 day walk out and not garnering any more benefits that what we were already offered. If Boeing doesn’t want to pay a pension benefit they won’t, they will hire engineers in a non-union environment. I agree we need to show strength but I just want to be certain it is not a foolish display. If you could inform me about the progress made in 2000 it would make me and my colleagues feel much better about putting our families in this potential predicament. Thanks, Kyle R. Rogers

Message.Title: Obama: Job of debt reduction nearly done
Message.Msg: One thing you won’t hear when President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday: An ambitious new plan to rein in the debt. In recent days, the White House has pressed the message that, if policymakers can agree on a strategy for replacing across-the-board spending cuts set to hit next month, the president will pretty much have achieved his debt-reduction goals. “Over the last few years, Democrats and Republicans have come together and cut our deficit [over the next decade] by more than $2.5 trillion through a balanced mix of spending cuts and higher tax rates for the wealthiest Americans. That’s more than halfway towards the $4 trillion in deficit reduction that economists and elected officials from both parties say we need to stabilize our debt,” Obama said during his weekend radio address. By the administration’s math, Washington needs to enact only another $1.5 trillion in 10-year savings to hit the $4 trillion target, White House economic adviser Jason Furman told reporters last week. At $1.2 trillion, the automatic cuts, known as the sequester, quite nearly fit the bill. The problem with this scenario? It would indeed stabilize the national debt, compared with the broader economy, for the next 10 years. But the debt would fluctuate between 73 percent and 77 percent of gross domestic product, according to new projections by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office — the highest level in U.S. history except for the period after World War II. It’s also much higher than the 62 percent target policymakers were aiming for just 3 years ago when Obama appointed the Bowles-Simpson debt-reduction commission. And because policymakers have avoided reforms to the big health and retirement programs, the debt would start rising again after 2023, as the baby boom generation retires.

Message.Title: Pelosi: We Don't Have a Spending Problem
Message.Msg: The latest bit of fiscal denialism from a high priestess of the pro-science "reality based community".... “We have to make a judgment about what -- how do we get growth with jobs, that is where the real revenue comes from. You don’t get it by…cutting your education and cutting back on investments in science and National Institutes of Health, food safety, you name it. So, it isn’t as much a spending problem as it is a priorities -- and that is what the budget is, setting priorities...So it is almost a false argument to say we have a spending problem, we have a budget deficit problem.” On one side of the aisle, we have Republicans asserting that we have a spending problem. On the other, Democrats insist that we have a revenue problem -- and that the outlays side of the equation isn't really about excessive spending, per se. The facts unambiguously demonstrate that conservatives are correct, and that liberals are either projecting deliberate dishonesty or dangerous self-delusion. What's especially mystifying is some powerful liberals' propensity to repackage the nation's spending problem as some other malady. President Obama calls it a "healthcare problem." (Well, yes, Mr. President; and a driving component of that problem is that we spend too much on healthcare, and that problem is getting worse, not better -- despite your ritual promises during the Obamacare debate). In this interview, Pelosi labels the issue a "budget deficit problem." (Well, yes, madam leader; our budget deficits are projected to remain perilously and historically high because we spend much, much more than we take in every single year). Our healthcare expenditure and budget deficit crises are by definition spending problems, a basic fact that the Left cannot fully acknowledge without reinforcing a prime argument for scaling back the scope of our rapacious government. Conservatives have spelled out America's spending problem over and over and over and over again. It's math. Anil Shivdasani Kenan-Flagler Business School, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Irina Stefanescu Kelley School of Business, Indiana University ... This article examines the capital structure implications of defined benefit corporate pension plans. The magnitude of the liabilities arising from these pension plans is substantial. We show that leverage ratios for firms with pension plans are about 35% higher when pension assets and liabilities are incorporated into the capital structure. We estimate that the tax shields from pension contributions are about a third of those from interest payments. Pension contributions have a modest effect in lowering firms’ marginal corporate tax rates. Once pensions are considered, firms are less conservative in their choice of leverage than has been previously thought.We show that firms incorporate the magnitude of their pension assets and liabilities into their capital structure decisions. (JEL G32, H20, J33) Investing in our pension as long as we get the tax deduction for it is a very good investment for us, Harry Stonecipher, president and chief executive officer of Boeing, told analysts in a third quarter conference call in October. Boeing’s $3.6 billion contribution in 2004 will result in a tax benefit that year of between $1.1 billion and $1.3 billion, assuming a tax rate of 30% to 35%, according to Boeing spokesman John Dern. —Wall Street Journal (2005), “How Companies Make the Most on Pensions”

In practice, such a strategy would create significant volatility in companies’ reported earnings as the value of pension assets and liabilities, and hence the required contributions, fluctuate over time. To avoid this variability, accounting rules allow companies to adopt several pension cost smoothing mechanisms. Because of these smoothing techniques, it is not uncommon for companies to report pension income as part of their operating income when, in fact, the funding status of their pension plan has deteriorated. As an example, in 2003, the Boeing Company reported pension liabilities of $39.9 billion and PA of $33.2 billion (a 17% underfunded plan) while reporting a pension income of $67 million on the income statement (i.e., a negative pension cost).
